Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The effect of development on evolution of a reproductive trait in Drosophila
Award.AbstractNarration:
The morphological differences within and between species are largely the result of differences in development. It is poorly understood how the development of an organ can impact the resulting adult morphology and how this might constrain or enhance evolution. This dissertation research will investigate the developmental basis of evolutionary change in ovarian morphology in Drosophilid flies. In these flies, as in all insects, the ovary is divided into substructures called ovarioles that act as assembly lines for egg production. The number of ovarioles has a large impact on reproductive capacity, as flies with more ovarioles can lay more eggs. Ovariole number can evolve rapidly among closely related species and is sometimes correlated with the specific environment (niche) where larvae feed and grow. The PIs will investigate ovary development of species with diverse ovariole numbers to understand (1) how different developmental changes alter ovariole number, and (2) how niche-specialization influences ovariole number evolution.

This project will combine lab and field work to provide insights into how the development of the ovary influences its evolutionary trajectory. In addition, this research will provide training for undergraduate students, including members of underrepresented minorities. Hawaiian Drosophilids will also be used to educate elementary school children at a local afterschool art program, where students will learn about the function of different morphological features through drawing.

DEB-1209570 Project Outcomes Report

 

Reproductive capacity refers to the ability of an organism to produce viable offspring. For sexually reproducing female animals, this is a function of the number of eggs they can produce, have successfully fertilized, and manage to lay or give birth to. This clearly depends in the first instance on the number of eggs that each female can make in her ovaries throughout her lifetime. Egg production is controlled by genetic factors, but can also be influenced by environmental factors including temperature and nutritional intake. Well-fed females of all species are capable of producing more eggs than starved females, and the same female on different diets may also produce different numbers of eggs. Our project proposed to examine how ecological conditions, including the availability of specific kinds of foods, and the genetic control of ovarian development, interact to determine egg-producing capacity.

 

To do this, we used fruit flies of the genus Drosophila as a model. These flies are easy to rear in the laboratory, and we have recently determined the specific developmental steps that the ovary has to go through in order to go from an undefined ball of cells in the embryo, to being a functional egg-producing organ in adults. We have focused our studies on Drosophila species that are native to the Hawaiian islands, for two reasons. First, different Hawaiian Drosophila species inhabit different environments on the different Hawaiian islands, and as a result, the nutritional intake of different species is very distinct. Some flies live on flower pollen, others on leaves, and yet others on fungi or rotting bark. Second, the range of egg-laying capacity is striking across these species, because they exhibit extreme variation in the number of egg-productive structures that they have in their ovaries; these structures are called ovarioles. Some Hawaiian Drosophila have only a few ovarioles per ovary, while others have over 100. This translates into vastly different egg-laying capabilities across the different species.

 

We went to Hawaii on three separate field trips and collected Hawaiian Drosophila from a range of habitats across the islands. We carefully recorded the types of habitats and food substrates that they were living on, as well as ovariole number and body size. Then we took these flies back to the laboratory, had them lay eggs, and observed the development of the ovaries of their offspring, to see what aspects of ovarian development were different between species with very different ovariole numbers.

 

At this point in our analysis, we have come to three major conclusions. First, the average ovariole number of these flies is essentially the same in wild-caught individuals, and in individuals reared in the laboratory. This means that genetic control of ovariole number must play an important role, because flies of the same species have the same average ovariole number whether they are eating laboratory food, or the food they would naturally eat in the wild. Second, although body size is usually a good predictor of ovariole number (larger flies tend to have more ovarioles), there are a number of species for which this is not true: some species have small bodies but many ovarioles, while others have large bodies but very few ovarioles. Third, there are two major developmental processes that appear to vary between species that have different ovariole numbers. These are the number of a specific cell type of the ovary that is important for generating ovarioles, and the organization of these specific cells into the structures that will allow the generation of ovarioles.
